body:
@xrmx The comments above (including yours) seem to suggest that the problem is a matter of taking a few minutes _before it works_. The problem is not that the query takes 5 minutes... (it's an incredibly small and simple query that takes a tenth of a second to return the table view). The problem is that it **never** renders a map. 

Never.

And it's not because of the query size or complexity, so profiling the query is time misspent. Is it a simple fix? Is there a way to simply force the correct Country encoding when the world-map is initially selected? Perhaps! But, I haven't found how to do that in the roughly 4 hours I've spent on this one visualization.

As for spending my own time on it trying to fix it: I plan to. However, I spent last week assessing Caravel: whether we wanted to use it internally and whether we wanted to recommend it to our clients, and I give my report tomorrow.

Hi @jasonshah, we're currently discussing the addition of a feature like this internally. Specifically we'd like to support an api for fetching a static image of a given chart or dashboard, which could then easily extended to send out emails automatically. 

Will post back as soon as we've settled on a technical solution for the implementation and have a better idea of the timeline. 

cc @ascott

Alanna, it's getting cut-off starting with the term SE_ADT_1525_LT_ ... on wards

@bkyryliuk 
So could you tell me what exactly those options mean ?
1) "Expose in SQL Lab"
2) "Allow Run Sync"
?

As written in the documentation windows is not a supported platform. As you have found out gunicorn does not work on windows. My advice would be to install it on a linux machine. Or you can use the development web server which of course is not advised to run in production.
ok, thanks

1) "Expose in SQL Lab" - makes the database available in the SQL Lab to query agaist
2) "Allow Run Sync" - there are 2 modes for running queries - sync and async. Async uses the celery backend and sync is executed within the request scope.
Async mode supports running long lasting queries, for instance hive.

To enable a database for sql lab both options have to be set.
@PickLiDan  - feel free to reopen is the issue persists. I cannot reproduce it.

@xrmx I see this issue as well.
I have created a slice that is a table view with 3 "non-grouped-by" columns and 1 ordered column ("collectionid [desc]").
The slice itself executes correctly when viewing it in isolation.
However, when I add it to a Dashboard and open the Dashboard, I see the same error message in red:

> order_by_cols: '[' is not a valid choice for this field

The only thing that looks like an error in the webserver output appears when I refresh the slice:

```
/dev/temp/caravel/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql/compiler.py:575: SAWarning: Can't resolve label reference u'collectionid'; converting to text() (this warning may be suppressed after 10 occurrences)
  util.ellipses_string(element.element))

```

I see no errors when I refresh the Dashboard.
(Is there another location to find error logs, other than the Terminal window in which I ran `caravel runserver`?)

I'm running Caravel 0.10.0, installed via pip on OS X.
@jasonshah could you please retry with latest git master?

Maybe not ideal but i don't see how that's a problem for a user.
For a user no, indeed, but for a company that wants to offer the tools to its customers it is, unless if this not the goal/intention of the community.
If you are doing SaaS GPL it is not an issue at all but thank you for pointing out the issue.

@ascott You mentioned that the visualizations should be converted to react. Is the plan to replace in the basic charts NVD3 with Victory? Do you plan to wrap the visualizations that use only D3 into react components? 

Switching from exploreV1 to exploreV2 gives the chance to implement faceting (e.g. multiple scatter plots in one viz, one for (a combination of) categorical variable(s) ). [Example](http://docs.ggplot2.org/0.9.3.1/facet_grid-10.png). Because the the subplots should use the same scaling for the data, there has to be some dependency between them.
+1, Looking forward to this too.

Alpha and Admin are special roles, some code rely on the exact names.

Permissions for tables iirc are created when you save the table, database, whatever. Also it does not make any sense to give a user more than one the default roles as Public and Gamma together. Usually you create other roles with specific permissions and compose what you need.

OK. Having recreated the sankey table from the example dataset, a new permission has appeared, so I can grant access to it via the public role. Might be worth stating this in the docs, as out of the box, you cannot assign permissions to the tables from the example data.

Re multiple roles, [the security docs](http://airbnb.io/caravel/security.html) give an example of using a 'finance' role to give access to a specific dataset/table to some users. This makes a lot of sense to me, so admin/alpha/gamma roles are used to say what a user can do, and custom roles can be used to allow access to specific datasets.

PR clarifying the docs much appreciated! :)

Re multiple roles, what i was trying to say is choose one of the default caravel roles and add your specific roles on top of them.

It works with node v6.6.0 and npm v3.10.8. You can install the node module n with npm. Then update node with n and npm with npm install npm@latest -g.
